title: Not my circus, not my monkeys
title_general: Not my circus, not my monkeys
definition: This troublesome, burdensome, or volatile situation is none of my concern, and thus I refuse to get involved in it. A loan translation of the Polish idiom

title: Waiting with baited breath
definition: To remain in a state of eager anticipation (of or for something).

title: People in glass houses shouldn’t throw stones
title_general: People (who live) in glass houses shouldn't throw stones.
definition: People who are vulnerable to criticism should not criticize others, especially not for the faults that they themselves have (since such criticism will likely be returned).

title: Don’t look a gift horse in the mouth
title_general: Don't look a gift horse in the mouth
definition: If you receive a gift, do so graciously, without voicing criticisms. The saying is attributed to St. Jerome and refers to the practice of looking at a horse''s teeth to determine its age.

title: Don’t count your chickens before they hatch
title_general: Don't count your chickens before they hatch.
definition: Don''t make plans based on future events, outcomes, or successes that might not come to pass.

title: Don’t keep all your eggs in one basket
title_general: put all (one's) eggs in one basket
definition: To invest, devote, or commit all of one''s energy or resources into a single venture, opportunity, or goal, generally at the risk of losing everything in the event that that thing fails or does not come to fruition.

title: A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush
title_general: A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush
definition: It is better to have something less valuable than to pursue something more valuable that may not be able to be obtained.

title: There’s more than one way to skin a cat
title_general: There's more than one way to skin a cat
definition: There are many methods one may employ in achieving one's ends.

title: Open a can of worms
definition: To initiate, instigate, or reveal a situation that is or is likely to become very complicated or problematic or that will have a negative outcome.

title: Bull in a china shop
title_general: A bull in a china shop
definition: Someone who is aggressively reckless and clumsy in a situation that requires delicacy and care.

title: One trick pony
definition: A person, group, or thing that is known for or limited to only one unique or noteworthy skill, talent, ability, quality, area of success, etc.

title: Don’t piss on my leg and tell me it’s raining
title_general: Piss on someone's leg and tell them it's raining
definition: To tell someone an obvious lie.

title: Too many chefs in the kitchen
title_general: Too many chefs in the kitchen
definition: Too many people are trying to control, influence, or work on something, with the quality of the final product suffering as a result. (A variation of the more common phrase, 'Too many chefs spoil the broth/stew/soup.'") "

title: If you can’t handle the heat get out of the kitchen
title_general: If you can''t stand the heat, get out of the kitchen
definition: Used as a way to tell someone that they should either stop complaining about a difficult or unpleasant activity, or stop doing it

title: Running on fumes
definition: Continuing to operate with no or very little enthusiasm, energy, or resources left. A reference to a car that has nearly run out of fuel.

title: One bad apple spoils the bunch
title_general: One bad apple spoils the (whole) bunch
definition: It only takes one person, thing, element, etc., to ruin the entire group, situation, project, etc. Refers to the fact that a rotting apple can cause other apples in close proximity to begin to rot as well.

title: The cream rises to the top
title_general: The cream (always) rises to the top
definition: Those with the most skill, the best work ethic, or the strongest moral character will inevitably find success in life.

title: Cut from same cloth
definition: Very similar in characteristics or behaviors.

title: Stick in the mud
definition: Someone who is considered boring, often due to unpopular or outdated beliefs.

title: Don’t rain on my parade
definition: Don't ruin one's plans or temper one's excitement.

title: Even the darkest storm cloud has a silver lining
definition: The potential for something positive or beneficial to result from a negative situation. Often used in the phrase 'every cloud has a silver lining.'" (A silver lining on a cloud is an indication that the sun is behind it.)"

title: Mess with a bull you get the horn
title_general: If you mess with the bull, you get the horns
definition: If you anger, irritate, or provoke someone enough, you will induce some hostile retaliation or emotional reaction.

title: It’s always darkest before dawn
definition: The worst part of an experience, situation, period of time, etc., usually happens just before things get better.

title: When it rains it pours
definition: When something good or bad happens, similarly good or bad things tend to follow.

title: Time and tide wait for no man
title_general: time and tide wait for no one
definition: The opportunities of life will pass you by if you delay or procrastinate in taking advantage of them.

title: Even a broken clock is right twice a day
title_general: a broken clock is right twice a day
definition: Even people who are usually wrong can be right sometimes, even if just by accident. From the idea that the stationary hands of a broken clock will still display the correct time at two points during the 24-hour cycle.

title: For whom the bell tolls
definition: Ernest Hemingway wrote

title: Make hay while the sun is shining
title_general: Make hay while the sun is shining
definition: To take advantage of favorable conditions; to make the most of an opportunity when it is available.

title: Mellow is the man who knows what he’s missing
Can’t teach an old dog new tricks
title_general: It's hard to teach an old dog new tricks
definition: It is exceptionally difficult to teach some new skill or behavior to someone, especially an older person, who is already firmly set in their ways.

title: Hindsight’s 20/20
definition: It is easier to clearly reevaluate past actions or decisions than when they are being made or done; things are clearer or more obvious when they are reflected upon. A reference to the visual acuity of normal eyesight (20/20 vision).

title: Give a mouse a cookie and he’ll ask for a glass of milk
Waking up on the wrong side of the bed
title_general: Wake up on the wrong side of (the) bed
definition: To be in a particularly and persistently irritable, unhappy, or grouchy mood or state, especially when it is not in line with one''s normal disposition.

title: Fair weather friend
definition: Someone who remains a friend only when things are going well but abandons others during times of trouble or difficulty.

title: Everything but the kitchen sink
definition: Nearly everything one can reasonably imagine; many different things, often to the point of excess or redundancy.

title: Give an inch and they take a mile
title_general: give an inch and they'll take a mile
definition: Make a small concession and they''ll take advantage of you. For example, I told her she could borrow the car for one day and she''s been gone a week-give an inch! This expression, in slightly different form, was already a proverb in John Heywood''s 1546 collection, 'Give him an inch and he''ll take an ell
contributor: '" and is so well known it is often shortened (as in the example). The use of mile dates from about 1900. "

title: The more the merrier
definition: More people will make something more enjoyable. Often used to welcome one to join a group or activity.

title: Measure twice cut once
definition: An axiom that encourages careful first steps in order to avoid extra work later on.

title: Give a man a fish, feed him for a day; teach a man to fish, feed him for a lifetime
definition: Simply giving someone a fish is not as helpful to them in the long run as teaching them how to fish.

title: You can bring a horse to water but can’t make it drink
definition: You can give someone an advantage or provide them with an opportunity, but you can''t force them to do something if they don''t want to

title: One man’s trash is another man’s treasure
title_general: One man's trash is another man's treasure
definition: What one person may consider worthless could be highly prized or valued by someone else.

title: Burning the candle at both ends
definition: To overwork or exhaust oneself by doing too many things, especially both late at night and early in the morning.

title: Polishing a turd
definition: To make something unpleasant seem more appealing than it really is—which is often a futile effort. 'Turd'" is a slang term for a piece of feces. "

title: Put lipstick on a pig, its still a pig
definition: Making superficial or cosmetic changes to a product in a futile effort to disguise its fundamental failings

title: One step forward two steps back
title_general: one step forward, two steps back
definition: Marked by a small amount progress that is then eradicated by a large amount of setbacks, problems, or difficulties.

title: It’s not over till the fat lady sings
title_general: It ain't over till/until the fat lady sings
definition: The final outcome cannot be assumed or determined until a given situation, event, etc., is completely finished. ('Ain''t'" is a colloquial contraction of '"is not.'") The phrase refers to the stereotypically stout female sopranos of the opera
timestamps: whose aria concludes Richard Wagner''s opera cycle "

title: Heavy is the head that wears the crown
title_general: heavy hangs the head that wears a/the crown
definition: The person who has the most power or authority suffers the largest amount of stress, anxiety, doubt, and worry. A misquote of the line 'Uneasy lies the head that wears a crown

title: An axe to grind
definition: A complaint or dispute that one feels compelled to discuss.

title: Big shoes to fill
definition: A role vacated or left behind by someone who was exceptional in their performance and set very high standards as a result.

title: The apple doesn’t fall far from the tree
title_general: The apple does not fall far from the tree
definition: Said when someone is displaying traits or behaving in the same way as their relatives (especially parents).

title: Chip off the old block
title_general: A chip off the old block
definition: Someone whose character or personality resembles that of their parent.

title: Chip on your shoulder
definition: An attitude that leads one to become combative or easily angered.

title: Reinvent the wheel
definition: To do something in a wholly and drastically new way, often unnecessarily. (Usually used in negative constructions.)

title: Two peas in a pod
definition: Two people who are very similar, typically in interests, dispositions, or beliefs.

title: Big fish in a small pond
title_general: A big fish in a small pond
definition: A situation in which one person has more power, influence, knowledge, or experience than others within a small group. It often implies that the person may not have as much clout in 'a bigger pond
timestamps: a larger group or arena of some kind. "

title: When pigs fly
definition: At a point in time that will never come to pass. (Used to show skepticism or cynicism over some hypothetical situation or outcome.)

title: When hell freezes over
definition: Never; at no time.

title: Out of the frying pan and into the fire
The pot calling the kettle black
title_general: The pot calling the kettle black
definition: A situation in which a person accuses someone of or criticizes someone for something that they themselves are guilty of.

title: You gotta kiss a lot of frogs to find a prince
Going to hell in a hand basket
title_general: Go to hell in a handbasket
definition: To be in an extremely and increasingly bad or ruinous condition; to be on the inevitable path to utter failure or ruin.

title: Bite off more then you can chew
The bigger they are the harder they fall
title_general: The bigger they are, the harder they fall
definition: Those who are exceptionally large, powerful, or influential will have more to lose when they fail, and their failure will be all the more dramatic or spectacular because of it.

title: The hair of the dog that bit you
title_general: The hair of the dog (that bit you)
definition: An alcoholic drink consumed to remedy a hangover. The phrase comes from the notion that literally rubbing the hair of the dog that bit you on the wound would help it to heal.

title: Wish in one hand and shit in the other
All who wander are not lost
All that glitters is not gold
title_general: All that glitters is not gold
definition: Things that have an outward appeal are often not as beautiful or valuable as they seem.

title: Diamond in the rough
definition: A person or thing with exceptional qualities or characteristics that cannot be seen from the surface.

title: Leave no stone unturned
definition: To look for something in every possible place.

title: No holds barred
definition: free of restrictions or hampering conventions

title: Throw the baby out with the bath water
title_general: Throw the baby out with the bath
definition: To discard something valuable or important while disposing of something considered worthless, especially an outdated idea or form of behavior. The phrase is often used in the negative as a warning against such thoughtless behavior.

title: Fall off the wagon
definition: To return to drinking alcohol after a period of abstinence. Usually said of recovering alcoholics.

title: Slow and steady wins the race
title_general: Slow and steady wins the race
definition: Persistent, consistent, and diligent progress, even if it is somewhat slow, will produce better results than rushing to get somewhere or achieve something, as the latter can result in mistakes or may prove unsustainable or unreliable. Derived from the classic Aesop fable of 'The Tortoise and the Hare
contributor: '" in which the titular tortoise is able to beat the hare in a race because the hare
column7: decides to take a nap along the way. "

title: Two sides to to the same coin
Play the hand you’re dealt
definition: To accept, deal with, and make the most of one''s current situation or circumstances; to make use of that which one is afforded or has available.

title: When life gives you lemons make lemonade
title_general: When life gives you lemons, make lemonade
definition: Focus on the good in a bad situation and take action accordingly.

title: Put a pin in it
definition: To take a break from discussing some topic, with plans to resume the discussion later.

title: The cherry on top
definition: The flourish that caps something off (much like a cherry tops off an ice cream sundae). Sometimes used in the phrase 'pretty please with a cherry on top.'" "

title: Icing on the cake
definition: An additional benefit or positive aspect to something that is already considered positive or beneficial.

title: The squeaky wheel gets the grease
title_general: The squeaky wheel gets the grease
definition: The person complaining or protesting the loudest or most frequently is the one who will receive the most attention from others.

title: Hell or high water
definition: By any means necessary; regardless of any difficulty, problem, or obstacle.

title: Stuck between a rock and a hard place
Skeletons in your closet
definition: An embarrassing or shameful secret. Primarily heard in US.

title: Skating on thin ice
definition: Engaged in some activity or behavior that is very risky, dangerous, or likely to cause a lot of trouble.

title: Flying too close to the sun
title_general: Fly too close to the sun
definition: To do something especially ambitious and daring that can or ultimately does lead to one''s own undoing or downfall. An allusion to the mythical figure Icarus, whose wings made of feathers and wax melted when he flew too close to the sun.

title: Toot your own horn
definition: To boast or brag about one''s own abilities, skills, success, achievements, etc.

title: Catch more flies with honey than vinegar
title_general: You (can) catch more flies with honey than (with) vinegar
definition: You are more likely to get the results you want from other people if you treat them with kindness or flattery, rather than being aggressive, demanding, or caustic.

title: Kill them with kindness
definition: To harm, inconvenience, or bother one by treating them with excessive favor or kindness. The phrase originated as the expression 'kill with kindness as fond apes do their young
contributor: '" referring to the notion that such animals sometimes crushed their offspring by hugging them too hard. "

title: Eye for an eye makes the whole world blind
title_general: An eye for an eye makes the whole world blind
definition: No good will result from avenging injuries in a manner equal to the original offense. The expression, widely attributed to Mahatma Gandhi, refers to the Biblical saying 'an eye for an eye
timestamps: '" which encourages vengeance that is equal to the original injury or offense. "

title: In the land of the blind the one eyed man is king
title_general: In the land of the blind, the one-eyed man is king
definition: Someone with few skills or abilities can impress and wield power over those who have even less to offer.

title: That ship has sailed
definition: Some possibility or option is no longer available or likely.

title: The pen is mightier than the sword
title_general: The pen is mightier than the sword
definition: Strong, eloquent, or well-crafted speech or writing is more influential on a greater number of people than force or violence.

title: Double edged sword
definition: Something that can be both beneficial and problematic.

title: I don’t have a dog in that fight
Spare the rod, spoil the child
Like water off a ducks back
The juice isn’t worth the squeeze
Can’t get blood from a stone
title_general: You can't get blood from a stone
definition: It is impossible to obtain something from someone if they are too parsimonious, uncharitable, or resolved against it.

title: Don’t judge a book by its cover
title_general: Don't judge a book by its cover
definition: Don't base your opinion of something (or someone) on the way it (or one) looks.

title: You can’t step into the same river twice
Stick a fork in me
definition: A phrase used to indicate that one or something is finished, complete, or no longer able to continue. Alludes to the practice of testing how thoroughly a piece of meat is cooked by piercing it with a fork.

title: This goose is cooked
definition: One is thoroughly defeated, ruined, or finished.

title: You shake it more than twice you’re playing with it
Why buy the cow when the milk is free
title_general: Why buy a/the cow when you can get (the) milk for free?
definition: If someone is already able to obtain some commodity or benefit freely or easily, then they won''t be inclined to pay for the source of it.

title: Don’t rock the boat
definition: Don't say or do something that could upset a stable situation.

title: If the shoe fits, wear it
title_general: If the shoe fits(, wear it)
definition: If something (typically negative) applies to one, one should acknowledge it or accept responsibility or blame for it.

title: Wrong side of the tracks
title_general: The wrong side of the tracks
definition: A part of a town or city that is particularly impoverished (and usually dangerous or undesirable as a result). 'Tracks'" refers to railroad tracks
contributor: which are sometimes thought of as demarcating different economic areas of a town. "

title: If it walks like a duck, talks like duck, it’s probably a duck
title_general: if it looks like a duck and walks like a duck, it is a duck
definition: If something has all the characteristics of a thing, it is probably that thing, regardless of what it is called or presented as. There are many variations of the expression, and it is often shortened to the first part of the phrase.

title: Waiting for the other shoe to drop
title_general: Waiting for the other shoe to drop
definition: To wait for the next, seemingly unavoidable (and typically negative) thing to happen.

title: Early bird gets the worm
title_general: The early bird catches the worm
definition: Someone who seizes some opportunity at the earliest point in time will have the best chance of reaping its benefits.

title: Let sleeping dogs lie
definition: To leave a situation alone so as to avoid worsening it.

title: A stitch in time saves nine
definition: A prompt, decisive action taken now will prevent problems later.

title: Every dog has his day
definition: Even the least fortunate person will have success at some point.

title: Reap what you sow
definition: To suffer the negative consequences of one's actions.

title: Till the cows come home
definition: For a very long, indefinite amount of time; forever.

title: Chickens come home to roost
definition: For a very long, indefinite amount of time; forever.

title: Oldest trick in the book
title_general: The oldest trick in the book
definition: A method of deception, or of addressing some issue, that is well known or has been used for a long time.

title: I’m picking up what you’re putting down
Biting the hand that feeds you
definition: To scorn or poorly treat those on whom you depend or derive benefit.

title: Put you’re money where your mouth is?
Get your ducks in a row
definition: To take action to become well-organized, prepared, or up-to-date.

title: As the crow flies
definition: The measurement of distance in a straight line. (From the notion that crows always fly in a straight line.)

title: The lights are on by nobody is home
Not playing with a full deck
title_general: Not playing with a full deck
definition: Not mentally sound; crazy or mentally deranged.

title: Walk a mile in someone’s shoes
definition: To spend time trying to consider or understand another person''s perspectives, experiences, or motivations before making a judgment about them.

title: This isn’t my first rodeo
definition: One is experienced with a certain situation, especially in relation to potential pitfalls or deceitful practices by others.

title: Bury the hatchet
definition: To make peace with someone.

title: Proof is in the pudding
title_general: The proof is in the pudding
definition: The final results of something are the only way to judge its quality or veracity.

title: Look what the cat dragged in
title_general: Look what the cat('s) dragged in
definition: A mild and usually playful insult used to announce someone's arrival and suggest that the person has a messy or otherwise disheveled physical appearance.

title: Spill the beans
definition: To reveal something that was meant to be a secret.

title: At loose ends
definition: Uneasy, typically due to some problem or unresolved issue.

title: Canary in a coal mine
definition: Something or someone who, due to sensitivity to his, her, or its surroundings, acts as an indicator and early warning of possible adverse conditions or danger. Refers to the former practice of taking caged canaries into coal mines. The birds would die if methane gas became present and thereby alert miners to the danger.

title: All hands on deck
definition: A call for all members of a ship''s crew to come to the deck, usually in a time of crisis. (A 'hand'" is a member of a ship''s crew.) "

title: Crying wolf
definition: To claim that something is happening when it really isn''t, which results in the rejection of subsequent valid claims. The expression comes from one of Aesop''s fables, in which a young shepherd lies about a wolf threatening his flock so many times that people do not believe him when he and his flock are legitimately in danger.

title: Cross your t’s dot your i’s
Over the moon
definition: Extremely happy.

title: Shoot for the stars
definition: To set one's goals or ambitions very high; to try to attain or achieve something particularly difficult.

title: Read between the lines
definition: To infer or understand the real or hidden meaning behind the superficial appearance of something. 'Lines'" refers to lines of text on a printed page. "

title: Put that in you’re pipe and smoke it
Rode hard and put away wet
title_general: Ride hard and put (something) away wet
definition: Of a horse, to ride it until a lather of sweat has formed, then put it into the stable without drying it. A noun or pronoun can be used between 'ride'" and '"hard.'" Primarily heard in US. "

title: Put the axe to the grindstone
A penny saved is a penny earned
title_general: A penny saved is a penny earned
definition: Every small amount helps to build one''s savings (i.e. by saving a penny, you have one more penny).

title: Key to my heart
definition: That which will make one very happy or content; the way to make one appreciate, like, or love someone else.

title: You can’t have your cake and eat it too
title_general: You can''t have your cake and eat it(, too)
definition: You cannot have or do two things that are both desirable but normally contradictory or impossible to have or do simultaneously. Because 'have'" can also mean '"eat
contributor: '" this expression may seem redundant. However
timestamps: it is based on the meaning of '"have'" as '"to possess
column8: to maintain possession of one''s cake while still eating it

title: Kill two birds with one stone
title_general: Kill two birds with one stone
definition: To complete, achieve, or take care of two tasks at the same time or with a singular series of actions; to solve two problems with one action or solution.

title: I don’t have a horse in that race
That’s the way the cookie crumbles
title_general: That's the way the cookie crumbles
definition: There is nothing we can do about the way things have unfolded, especially bad ones, so there is no reason to be upset about it.

title: A straight arrow
definition: An honest, ethical person who makes good decisions.

title: On the straight and narrow
definition: Maintaining a morally upright way of life; only making choices that are considered morally and legally correct.

title: Every rose has its thorn
definition: There is rarely a good or positive thing, event, or circumstance that is not accompanied by some aspect that is negative or unpleasant.

title: Lightning never strikes the same place twice
title_general: Lightning never strikes (the same place) twice
definition: Something that's very extraordinary and unlikely to happen will never happen to the same person twice. (Said especially of tragic or unfortunate events.)

title: Dog eat dog world
definition: A society, situation, industry, etc. characterized by ruthless behavior and competition.

title: It’s a small world after all
Smoke em if you got em
On the tip of your tongue
definition: Almost able to be recalled.

title: Babe in the woods
definition: A person who is gullible, naïve, or lacks experience in a specific situation.

title: Cold feet
definition: Nervousness or anxiety felt before one attempts to do something.

title: Caught red handed
definition: To see, and perhaps apprehend, someone as they are doing something (often something nefarious). The phrase might have originally referred to blood on a murderer''s hands.

title: On the fence
definition: Not making a decision or taking a side when presented with two options or possibilities; undecided.

title: In the weeds
definition: Of a restaurant worker, completely overwhelmed with diners'' orders and unable to keep up with the pace.

title: Putting the cart before the horse
title_general: Put the cart before the horse
definition: To do things out of the proper order.

title: Paint the town red
definition: To go out into a city or town and have an enjoyable time, typically by visiting various establishments, such as bars, restaurants, clubs, etc.

title: Pipe dream
definition: A dream or idea that is impossible to accomplish.

title: Don’t blow smoke up my ass
Monkey see monkey do
definition: Children naturally tend to imitate or copy what they see adults or other children doing.

title: Pull yourself up by your bootstraps
definition: To improve one''s life or circumstances through one''s own efforts, rather than relying on others.

title: Rat race
definition: A fierce competition for success, wealth, or power.

title: Written in stone
definition: Permanently fixed or firmly established; incapable of being changed. Often used in the negative.

title: Smooth sailing
definition: Progress or advancement that is free from difficulties, obstacles, or challenges.

title: Shooting blanks
definition: Of a man, to have a low sperm count in his semen.

title: Blacker the berry sweeter the juice
Over my dead body
definition: I will never allow it; under no circumstances will that be permitted to happen (i.e., something can only happen if I am not alive to prevent it).

title: Raise the roof
definition: To engage in loud, unrestrained, and boisterous behavior, especially at a party or while celebrating.

title: It takes village to raise a child
Below the belt
definition: Unfairly targeted at one''s weakness or vulnerability. The phrase refers to boxing, in which hitting an opponent below the waist is prohibited.

title: 0 to 60
definition: To accelerate from a standstill to sixty miles per hour. Used to indicate how quickly a vehicle, especially an automobile, can accelerate.

title: Turn on a dime
definition: To turn very quickly and with great agility.

title: Once bitten twice shy
definition: Once one is hurt by someone or something, one will be extra cautious to avoid that person or thing.

title: The road to hell is paved with good intentions
title_general: The road to hell is paved with good intentions
definition: Good intentions do not matter if a person's actions lead to bad outcomes.

title: Don’t shit where you eat
definition: Do not engage in troublesome or dubious behavior at one''s home, place of business, or any location where one frequents, for it invites undesired consequences.

title: Don’t dip the pen in company ink
Pulling your leg
definition: To tease or joke with someone, often by trying to convince them of something untrue.

title: Glass half empty
definition: Of or characterized by a generally pessimistic worldview. (Typically hyphenated and used as a modifier before a noun.)

title: Strike gold
definition: Literally, to discover gold, as in a gold mine.

title: Ruling with an iron fist
definition: To rule, govern, or control a group or population with complete, typically tyrannical authority over all aspects of life, work, etc. A noun or pronoun can be used between 'rule'" and '"with.'" "

title: Now we’re cooking with gas
definition: Now one is making progress or doing something right.

title: Dumpster fire
definition: A complete and utter disaster or a completely chaotic situation, likened to a fire in a dumpster, which quickly becomes uncontrollable. The phrase can be applied to both situations and people.

title: Bigger fish to fry
definition: More important matters to deal with.

title: Jerking your chain
definition: To tease someone, often by trying to convince them of something untrue.

title: Stop and smell the roses
definition: To take time to enjoy the finer or more enjoyable aspects of life, especially when one has become overworked or overly stressed.

title: Slippery slope
definition: A situation in which some behavior or action will eventually lead to a worse form of the same behavior or action, or a disastrous outcome.

title: Pick your battles
definition: To choose not to participate in minor, unimportant, or overly difficult arguments, contests, or confrontations, saving one''s strength instead for those that will be of greater importance or where one has a greater chance of success.

title: On my last leg
definition: Near physical collapse or death.

title: Watch a pot it never boils
The tip of the iceberg
title_general: Just the tip of the iceberg
definition: Only a small, often unrepresentative portion of something much larger or more complex that cannot yet be seen or understood.

title: Needle in a haystack
definition: Something that is very difficult to locate.

title: Still waters run deep
definition: Quiet people have interesting, profound, or complex thoughts.

title: An elephant never forgets
definition: One remembers everything. A play on the idea that elephants have great memories.

title: Trojan horse
definition: Something that initially seems innocuous but is ultimately bad or malicious. A reference to the myth in which Ancient Greek soldiers hid inside a giant wooden horse in order to gain access to the city of Troy.

title: Where there’s smoke there’s fire
definition: When there is some indication of a problem or wrongdoing, such a thing probably occurred or exists.

title: Shot in the dark
definition: A guess or estimate with very little or no assurance as to its accuracy.

title: If you can’t beat ‘em join em
Low hanging fruit
definition: That which is especially easy to obtain or achieve. Often implies something that is perhaps not as satisfying as that which takes more effort or skill to obtain or do.

title: Throw down the gauntlet
definition: To issue a challenge or invitation, as to a fight, argument, or competition.

title: Getting your foot in the door
title_general: Get a/(one's) foot in the door
definition: To have a chance to do something that could lead to further opportunities. The phrase is often used to refer to employment.
